etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in The Cornhill Magazine. From Old French (northern) cantefable from canter, variant of chanter to sing + fable

definitions: A medieval French ballad, in which passages in spoken prose alternate with passages in sung verse; this as a literary genre.

notes.text: Often with reference to the 13th-cent. text Aucassin et Nicolette, in which the term occurs in Old French.

definitions: Any text or work, especially a folk tale, consisting partly of prose and partly of (sung or recited) verse.

notes.text: Frequently associated with African-American or Caribbean culture.
